properties.media:imagetext:
#5
Saturday,
October
boat docked
transferred
We arrived
at Nanking
without incident.
three miles upstream
Nanking Bund and we
which brought us (standing in the
fain on front
There we hired the
Ford taxi
out for the American Embassy.
in as ay. pue main drag chang
Otherwise the capital
as quiet and untouched by war as before the
present hostilities began.
Several
bomb scars have xxxxx
since been pointed
out to me but
are discernible.
None of
large public buildings has been hit
though many have been the
target of
raids.
are living at the American Embassy with Mr. Peck who very
invited us
live with him during our stay in Nanking.
Mr. Peck had a dinner party
with Ambassador Johnson,
a Dr. and Mrs.
and their
twenty year old daughter.
They were
charming
Germans
spoke
excellent English.
Dr. Hershberg
surgeon
some remarkable
operations and is gelping
dously in the present
Chinese hospital
management.
is suspected
that he left a good practice in
to avoid persecution
by Hitlerites.
After ainner we
"Poker Patience".
There was no bomb raid as the
weather continued.
Sunday AM, October
Yesterday
also a bad day
- therefore a
Our managing
arrived from Hankow having been unable
to join us Friday because the
airplane schedule was cancelled
that day
account
We had a session
with him - went to
International Club where most of the foreigners remaining in Nanking
congregate every Saturday night to make a little whoople up to curfew
time at 11 PM.
I met many old friends there and had a fine time.
There was only one woman present - a French girl who
arrived here a few
weeks ago as a volunteer nurse - fell in love with a French newspaper
correspondent and was married night before last.
The whole town turned
out for the wedding.
Women in Nanking are so scarce that
whenever you
see one you stamp your hand as the kids do when they
see a white horse.
About 80% of the foreign population of Nanking has gone.
I had a long talk with Mr.Holm, a good friend of ours,
to be Postal Commissioner at Chungking.
He has resigned and is keen on
returning with Mrg.Holm to his "home"
in Copenhagen
after thirty years
I wonder if they won't soon want to come back.
at Chungking, Mr. Holm was a real personage.
rounded by a lovely garden.
travelled to work in a grand sedan chair
fitted out like a small throne, borne by four uniformea
chair coolies.
He had a No.l boy who ran the house and looked after every detail from
food to pressing his suits and shining his boots.
Several coolies were
at his beck and call to run errands,. bring him
whatever he
called for, etc.
Three gardeners
cared for his garden as though it were their own.
will be different in Copenhagen.
Later - Sunday night - rain and low ceiling all day.
conference
Had long
with Vice-Minister of Communications
which lasted all morning
and accomplished nothing.
Very discouraging.
Lunch with Mr. Peck and
Mr. Johnson, also dinner - much conversation but no results.
American
attitude very sympathetic and helpful,
Chinese
very unsympathetic and
non-co-operative.
Some Chinese officials can be unbelievably dull and
stupid.
Our friend of today's conference seems intent only on immediate
necessities to the exclusion of all else.
Hope for better luck tomorrow.
SEONSI
